awd_titl_txt: NCS-FO: Sub-millisecond Optically-triggered Compound Release to Study Real-time Brain Activity and Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
1631910
Qin, Zhenpeng

Understanding how the brain controls behavior requires advanced tools to manipulate brain activity. Inspired by recent progress in optogenetics (i.e., a technique to control selected types of brain cells with genetic modification and light stimulation), this project seeks to develop a new set of tools that will allow localized and ultrafast control of brain activity to influence behavior in freely-moving animals. This will be achieved by using light stimulation to rapidly release compounds that are encapsulated in tiny nanometer-sized particles. The ultrafast feature of this novel compound technology is ideally suited to manipulate brain activity that typically occurs on the scale of milliseconds. Importantly, this new technology is suited to packaging and releasing a wide range of chemical and biological compounds, as well as combinations of such compounds. The project's success will have a number of broader impacts. Scientifically, this project will generate a new technology to better understand how the brain works, and thus new knowledge about the brain and behavior. The ultrafast compound release method can potentially develop into a platform technology for other research areas, including the nervous system outside the brain. The collaborative environment of this project will provide interdisciplinary training opportunities for two graduate students with cutting-edge technologies in the fields of engineering and neuroscience. Finally, this project will promote STEM education both in the lab and through community outreach programs.  
 
Advances in methodologies and tools for neuroscience research often lead to fundamental insights into the function of the central and periphery nervous system. Currently available methods for drug infusions using relatively large metal cannulas are not ideal for studies in freely behaving animals, because drug delivery is slow and the cannulas often destroy the brain area under study and/or overlying brain areas. New methods are needed to perform drug infusion or local release in a minimally invasively manner in freely moving animals. Inspired by recent developments in optogenetics, the PIs will develop a versatile optically-triggered system for sub-millisecond compound burst release for the real-time study of brain activity and behavior. Plasmonic liposomes, i.e. liposomes coated with a gold shell layer, can encapsulate a wide range of molecular compounds and be deposited locally in the brain. Due to the small width and poor clearance of the extracellular space in the brain, the plasmonic liposomes can be designed to stay in the injected area for prolonged periods of time. The encapsulated compound can then be quickly burst-released by a near-infrared pulsed laser via an implanted optical fiber. The encapsulated compounds can be designed to release by repeated triggers, allowing multiple on-demand drug release events over an extended period for behavioral studies. In this project, an integrated approach will be developed to deliver and release the encapsulated compounds, and to study the resulting brain activity and behavior change in real-time utilizing Pavlovian fear conditioning. Successful development of this sub-millisecond optically-triggered burst release technique will represent a major technological advancement that addresses the limitations of current techniques for behavioral research. Specifically, improved bio-compatibility and reduced invasiveness are anticipated by the by one-time nanoparticle infusion and on-demand light-triggered drug release. The fast release feature of the new technique will provide sufficient speed to study neuronal communication in neuroscience research. Furthermore, this technique will find wide applications in neuropharmacology research where targeted delivery and localized rapid release are currently unavailable.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to develop optical and nanomaterials techniques to study real-time brain activity and behavior. Our cross-disciplinary collaboration and investigations have led several important advances. First, we have prepared and characterized the gold-coated nanovesicles and demonstrated that it can release the encapsulated compound within 0.1 millisecond, an order of magnitude faster than any existing opto-release system, upon short laser pulse excitation. We have investigated the optical properties of gold-coated nanovesicles by numerical simulation and revealed important characteristic regimes that govern how the peak absorption shifts from visible to near-infrared wavelengths. With this system, we have demonstrated the ability to manipulate intracellular signaling with high spatiotemporal control by the on-demand release of messenger molecules. Second, we have discovered that laser-generated plasmonic nanobubble and the corresponding mechanotransduction significantly improve the gene transfection and protein expression inside living cells, compared with standard electroporation treatment alone. Third, we have developed a novel gold-coated mechanoresponsive liposomes by reducing gold ions onto a unique lipid structure called ?Rad-PC-Rad?. This system allows photoreleasing molecules with a very low light intensity and thus in deep brain regions in a mouse model. Fourth, we have investigated packaging a neuropeptide inside plasmonic liposomes, and upon photorelease, how the peptide modulator send signal to nearby distances, a phenomenon called volume transmission. We found that the the peptide transmission is faster in the brain with compromised extracellular matrix compared with a normal brain. Lastly, we have developed a ?molecular hyperthermia? strategy that selectively target and inactivate the protein with gold nanoparticles and a single nanosecond laser pulse. We have applied the strategy to inactivate two important protein targets that are involved in pain signaling and blood-brain barrier maintenance, all in live cells and without compromising the cell proliferation. In summary, we have developed several optical tools for modulating protein activity, cell signaling, brain activity and behavior. 

Intellectual Merit: These techniques have made a significant impact on engineering and neuroscience. First, the ultrafast, opto-release technique offers an unprecedented speed and flexibility to locally release compounds that are important in the brain and behavioral neuroscience research. The sub-millisecond release has proven to be sufficient for studying the brain activity including millisecond neurotransmission. Our method is flexible for packaging and releasing different chemical and biological compounds. Second, our research has built new tools that enable researching the endogenous and exogenous compounds and revealed how they transmit signals in the brain.  

Broader Impacts: The research has generated several broader impacts. First, we have developed new optical and nano-tools to control molecular release and activity in live cells and in vivo. Our project has generated new knowledge to better understand the properties of nanomaterials, their photorelease characteristics, and the use of the technology to determine how neurotransmitters send signal across microscopic distances. The developed opto-release method has become a platform technology to study other important questions on neuromodulation. Second, this project has trained three graduate students in an interdisciplinary and collaborative environment involving engineering and neuroscience. Third, the PIs have been working with women, underrepresented minorities, and undergraduate students in this research project. Finally, the PIs have worked with K?12 outreach programs during the research project.
